I see why you should wash your hands, you don't want let's say the flu for example, but at the same time, if people say that having longer nails makes your hands all in all dirtier, and that there's a lot of germs under the nails (Or at the least in that area) then... what? Although Hand Sanitizer can be useful when you cannot get to a sink, I agree with the stance in this video that it is far better if you simply wash your hands. Hand Sanitizer kills the majority of germs that propagate on your hands but the tiny percentage that survives might still be able to thrive and cause problems. Besides, the germs are still on your hands even if dead until you wash them off. When done properly hand washing can force the germs off of your hands and down the drain, which eliminates the need for hand sanitizer. The reason is that soap’s function is to trap the bacteria, so that when you wash the soap off you are taking the bacteria alongside it. Besides that, soap and water can remove visible dirt and grime that hand sanitizer isn’t quite so effective at eliminating from your hands. As for antibacterial soaps it could be stated that using any soap that kills germs could be considered overkill mostly because by washing you are already sending the germs away, yet the main reasons to avoid any specific soap would primarily be if that soap has ingredients that harm the environment, or if you have an allergy to an ingredient in the soap type (which might be a problem in the case of some scented soaps; example: almond oil in a fragrance when you have a nut allergy). In conclusion, hand sanitizer should only be used as a way to minimize germs when you cannot get to a sink beforehand.

At what point did you answer the question posed by the video? Also, the number of places you can use hand sanitizers dwarfs the places where a sink is available for soup / water / drying. Also, hand sanitizers are much easier to do and take less time. Also, honestly, how often does anyone wash their hands for 40s. You're lucky if someone even washes their hands, much less for more than 10s. It's important to think about things from a behavioral point of view. Sure, there might be things that work better than hand sanitizers, but will people use them and in the appropriate way? If no one washes their hands unless there is visible dirt on them, then telling people to wash their hands for 40s doesn't solve any problem. Hand sanitizers being much more conveniently placed and used makes them much more likely to prevent the spread of disease than expecting people to wash their hands (how often?) for 40s.

Your description of the results of the 2009 study are misleading. You mention that only the hand-washing group removed viral DNA from human skin. But this is not necessarily relevant. Although sanitizers do not remove viral DNA from skin, they still render the virus dead and harmless. Cultured samples showed that sanitizer reduced the threat of infection nearly as well as washing and that "alcohol-based hand rub is highly effective in reducing influenza A virus on human hands". In real life practical situations, the sanitizer groups would likely perform better than washing because most people do not wash their hands with soap and water for 40 seconds (the CDC recommends at least 20 seconds).

Another mistake is that you claim that hot water must be hot near boiling to be effective. The purpose of warm water when washing hands is not to kill germs with heat. Rather, the temperature of the water helps soap and water dissolve and remove the skin oils where germs attach to the skin.

Good video - but I have one issue.
Saying to always wash your hands with cold water in contrast to warm or hot water is incorrect.
The hot water may not be effective enough to kill bacteria but the warmer water is able remove oils easier from the hand and is more effective than cold water at cleaning your hands. (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15824636?ordinalpos=1&itool=EntrezSystem2.PEntrez.Pubmed.Pubmed_ResultsPanel.Pubmed_DefaultReportPanel.Pubmed_RVDocSum)
Cold water is terrible for washing hands if you have any noticeable amount of oils or grease.  The higher the temperature of the water, the more quickly such substances will wash away with soap.

Source from World Health Organization: http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/44102/1/9789241597906_eng.pdf
Pg. 152

This video contains false or misleading information based on a study which did not measure bacterial or viral presence, but only the presence of their DNA. Alcohol-based rubs destroy the bacterial membrane and viral envelope effectively making reproduction and infection impossible in 99.99% of cases. Soap kills some bacteria and some viruses, but it leaves plenty more behind which are alive and able to cause infection. The reason the concentration of DNA on hands was higher in the trial you mentioned is because the Alcohol killed all the microbes, but left harmless DNA behind, while the handwashing removed some microbes and killed some, but left some able to reproduce and infect behind. Loose DNA is not dangerous and cannot cause infections. You are trying to form causation based off correlation in your assumption that more DNA=more live microbes when that is just not the case.

Alcohol-based solutions are also better for hand health and moisture.

Couple of minor mistakes in this video:

1:16 should be isopropanol (or isopropyl alcohol) instead of isoproponal
1:52 the structure for triclosan is wrong.
a) the bridging oxygen should be bound by single bonds, not double bonds
b) the rings should be aromatic phenyl rings (so three double bonds instead of the one that is shown)
c) triclosan has only one hydroxy-group, and three chloride groups, one in ortho-position to the hydroxy, one replacing the other hydroxy-group shown in this video, and the last in ortho-position towards that.
